Chemical Engineer University of Massachusetts Amherst September 2005  –  September 2010  (5 years 1 month) 1) Silicon Thin Films: 
•	Researched, analyzed, and resolved outstanding issues in plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition (CVD) of amorphous silicon (a-Si:H) thin films, allowing the design of systematic strategies to optimize film properties: 
•	Established the growth mechanism of a:Si-H thin films that fully explains experimental data, using density functional theory (DFT), Molecular-dynamics (MD), and kinetic-Monte Carlo (KMC) simulations. 
•	Modeled, characterized, and determined structure-property relationships of a-Si:H thin films, enabling better performance of electronic and photovoltaic devices.  
 
2) Carbon Nanotubes 
 
•	Analyzed and modeled hydrogen plasma exposure of multi-walled carbon nanotubes (CNTs) to enable potential applications of CNTs in hydrogen storage devices: 
•	Elucidated the H-induced transitions of CNTs to diamond nanocrystals using DFT and MD simulations resulting in new recipes to synthesize diamond crystals at the nanoscale. 
•	Established a novel allotrope of carbon and characterized new carbon nanostructures. Validated with Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM), Raman spectroscopy, and Electron diffraction. 
 
3) Compound semiconductor nanocrystals 
 
•	Synthesized and characterized doped colloidal semiconductor nanocrystals (quantum dots of ZnSe & ZnO) that have applications in nanoelectronics, spintronics, and solar cells: 
•	Explained the fundamental doping mechanism in nanocrystals based on a novel surface kinetic-growth model. Proposed novel experiments toward optimal design of doped quantum dots. 
•	Designed and developed a novel optimization scheme based on simulated annealing. Implemented this technique to successfully local global minima of the structures of compound semiconductor clusters.
